NDAlias

A class to access the Alias Manager from Cocoa.

Version:

1.3
Conforms to:

NSCoding
Superclass: NSObject
Declared In: NDAlias

Discussion

Your application can use an NDAlias to refer to file system objects (that is, files, directories, and volumes) in a way that does expect the file system object's path to be maintained. The user then can move or rename the file system object without your program losing track of it. This behaviour is not always desirable, for instance with library resources. But for file system objects like documents or user folders, it is what Mac OS users have come to expect.


Groups

Obtain the aliases data

Group members:

-data

Returns a NSData instance for the reciever.

 

Update the path of the alias

Group members:

-setPath:

Updates an the reciever with a new target.

-setPath:fromPath:

Updates an the reciever with a new target.

-setURL:

Updates an the reciever with a new target.

-setURL:fromURL:

Updates an the reciever with a new target.

-setURL:fromURL:

Updates an the reciever with a new target.

 

Information about an alias

Group members:

-allowUserInteraction

Option controls how the alias is resolved

-changed

Reports whether the receiver was updated.

 

Miscellaneous

Group members:

-displayName

Returns a NSString of the receiver's filename in the correct localized form.

-isEqualToAlias:

Test alias equality

-lastKnownName

Return name from an alias record

-lastKnownPath

Return path from an alias record

-lastKnownVolumeName

Return volume from an alias record

-resolveIfIsAliasFile:

Resolve alias file target.

 

Setting the way the alias is resolved

Group members:

-setAllowUserInteraction:

Option controls how the alias is resolved

-setTryFileIDFirst:

Option controls how the alias is resolved

-tryFileIDFirst

Option controls how the alias is resolved

 

Obtain the path the alias points to.

Group members:

-DEPRECATED_ATTRIBUTE
-path

Returns the single most likely target for the receiver.

-URL

Returns the single most likely target for the receiver.

aliasWithData:

Creates and initalises an NDAlias. 

+ (id)aliasWithData:(NSData *)data;
Parameters
data

The NSData instances that contains the data returned previously from the method data.

Return Value

A NDAlias instance, returns nil if NDAlias creation fails.

Discussion

The method aliasWithData: creates an NDAlias that describes the specified target. aliasWithData: creates the NDAlias from the data that was returned from the method data

aliasWithFSRef:

Creates and initalises an NDAlias. 

+ (id)aliasWithFSRef:(FSRef *)aFSRef;
Parameters
aFSRef

An FSRef instance that points to the object to make an alias of.

Return Value

A NDAlias instance, returns nil if NDAlias creation fails.

Discussion

The method aliasWithFSRef: creates an NDAlias that describes the specified target. aliasWithFSRef: creates the NDAlias from the provided FSRef.

aliasWithPath:

Creates and initalises an NDAlias. 

+ (id)aliasWithPath:(NSString *)path;
Parameters
path

the path for the target of the alias.

Return Value

An NDAlias instance, returns nil if NDAlias creation fails.

Discussion

The method aliasWithPath: creates an NDAlias that contains only the minimum information necessary to describe the target: the target name, the parent directory ID, the volume name and creation date, and the volume mounting information. The aliasWithPath: method uses the standard alias record data structure, but it fills in only parts of the record.

The methods URL and path never update a minimal alias record.

aliasWithPath:fromPath:

Creates and initalises an NDAlias. 

+ (id)aliasWithPath:(NSString *)path fromPath:(NSString *)fromPath;
Parameters
URL

the file url for the target of the alias.

fromPath

The starting point for a relative path, to be used later in a relative search. The two file or directory url's, fromPath and URL, must reside on the same volume.

Return Value

A NDAlias instance, returns nil if NDAlias creation fails.

Discussion

The method aliasWithPath:fromPath: creates an NDAlias that describes the specified target. aliasWithPath:fromPath: always records the name and file or directory ID of the target, its creation date, the parent directory name and ID, and the volume name and creation date. It also records the full pathname of the target and a collection of other information relevant to locating the target, verifying the target, and mounting the target's volume, if necessary. aliasWithPath:fromPath: also stores relative path information as well by supplying a starting point for a relative path.

aliasWithURL:

Creates and initalises an NDAlias. 

+ (id)aliasWithURL:(NSURL *)URL;
Parameters
URL

the file url for the target of the alias.

Return Value

An NDAlias instance, returns nil if NDAlias creation fails.

Discussion

The method aliasWithURL: creates an NDAlias that contains only the minimum information necessary to describe the target: the target name, the parent directory ID, the volume name and creation date, and the volume mounting information. The aliasWithURL: method uses the standard alias record data structure, but it fills in only parts of the record.

The methods URL and path never update a minimal alias record.

aliasWithURL:fromURL:

Creates and initalises an NDAlias. 

+ (id)aliasWithURL:(NSURL *)URL fromURL:(NSURL *)fromURL;
Parameters
URL

the file url for the target of the alias.

fromURL

The starting point for a relative path, to be used later in a relative search. The two file or directory url's, fromURL and URL, must reside on the same volume.

Return Value

An NDAlias instance, returns nil if NDAlias creation fails.

Discussion

The method aliasWithURL:fromURL: creates an NDAlias that describes the specified target. aliasWithURL:fromURL: always records the name and file or directory ID of the target, its creation date, the parent directory name and ID, and the volume name and creation date. It also records the full pathname of the target and a collection of other information relevant to locating the target, verifying the target, and mounting the target's volume, if necessary. aliasWithURL:fromURL: also stores relative path information as well by supplying a starting point for a relative path.

allowUserInteraction

Option controls how the alias is resolved 

- (BOOL)allowUserInteraction;
Return Value

Returns YES if user interaction is allowed.

Discussion

Gets wether the OS may present a user interface when resolving the receiver. By default, as of version 1.3, user interaction is not allowed. In previous versions, the default was to allow user interaction.

changed

Reports whether the receiver was updated. 

- (BOOL)changed;
Return Value

YES if the receiver was updated, NO if it was not updated.

Discussion

The method changed indicates whether the receiver was updated because it contained some outdated information about the target. If it the receiver is updated, YES is returned. Otherwise, it return NO. (URL and path never update an NDAlias that was created with no relative path.)

data

Returns a NSData instance for the reciever. 

- (NSData *)data;
Return Value

Returns an NSData instance.

Discussion

The method data returns the contents of the recievers as an NSData, this can be used for archiving purposes though NDAlias does implement the NSCoding protocol.

DEPRECATED_ATTRIBUTE

- (NSURL *)url DEPRECATED_ATTRIBUTE;
Discussion

This method is deprecated. Use -URL instead. Why? For consistency with Cocoa classes, which spell it in caps.

displayName

Returns a NSString of the receiver's filename in the correct localized form. 

- (NSString *)displayName;
Return Value

Returns an NSString instance.

Discussion

The method displayName returns the filename in the correct localized form, taking into account ':' <-> '/' transformations and localized display names.

initWithData:

Initalises an NDAlias. 

- (id)initWithData:(NSData *)data;
Parameters
data

The NSData instances that contains the data returned previously from the method data.

Return Value

An initalised NDAlias, returns nil if initialisation fails.

Discussion

The method initWithData: initalises an NDAlias that describes the specified target. initWithData: creates the NDAlias from the data that was returned from the method data

Initalises an NDAlias. 

- (id)initWithFSRef:(FSRef *)aFSRef;
Parameters

An FSRef instance that points to the object to make an alias of.

Return Value

An initalised NDAlias, returns nil if initialisation fails.

Discussion

The method initWithFSRef: initalises an NDAlias that describes the specified target. initWithFSRef: creates the NDAlias from the provided FSRef.

initWithPath:

Initalises an NDAlias. 

- (id)initWithPath:(NSString *)path;
Parameters
path

the path for the target of the alias.

Return Value

An initalised NDAlias, returns nil if initialisation fails.

Discussion

The method initWithPath: initalises an NDAlias that contains only the minimum information necessary to describe the target: the target name, the parent directory ID, the volume name and creation date, and the volume mounting information. The initWithPath: method uses the standard alias record data structure, but it fills in only parts of the record.

The methods URL and path never update a minimal alias record.

initWithPath:fromPath:

Initalises an NDAlias. 

- (id)initWithPath:(NSString *)path fromPath:(NSString *)fromPath;
Parameters
path

the file url for the target of the alias.

fromPath

The starting point for a relative path, to be used later in a relative search. The two file or directory url's, fromPath and path, must reside on the same volume.

Return Value

An initalised NDAlias, returns nil if initialisation fails.

Discussion

The method initWithPath:fromPath: initalises an NDAlias that describes the specified target. initWithPath:fromPath: always records the name and file or directory ID of the target, its creation date, the parent directory name and ID, and the volume name and creation date. It also records the full pathname of the target and a collection of other information relevant to locating the target, verifying the target, and mounting the target's volume, if necessary. initWithPath:fromPath: also stores relative path information as well by supplying a starting point for a relative path.

isEqualToAlias:

Test alias equality 

- (BOOL)isEqualToAlias:(id)otherObject;
Discussion

Returns YES if the receiver is equal to the passed object. Two NDAliases are defined as equal if and only if they resolve to equal FSRefs. Alias resolution is performed on both aliases, if there is any error, NO is returned.

lastKnownName

Return name from an alias record 

- (NSString *)lastKnownName;
Discussion

This method returns the name from the alias record. The information is gathered only from the alias record, so it may not match what is on disk. No disk input/output is performed.

lastKnownPath

Return path from an alias record 

- (NSString *)lastKnownPath;
Discussion

This method returns the path from the alias record. The information is gathered only from the alias record, so it may not match what is on disk. No disk input/output is performed.

lastKnownVolumeName

Return volume from an alias record 

- (NSString *)lastKnownVolumeName;
Return Value

<#result#>

Discussion

This method returns the volume from the alias record. The information is gathered only from the alias record, so it may not match what is on disk. No disk input/output is performed.

path

Returns the single most likely target for the receiver. 

- (NSString *)path;
Return Value

A path NSString to the target of the receiver. nil is returned if no target could be found.

Discussion

The method path performs a fast search for the target of the receiver. If the resolution is successful, path returns a path NSString for the target file system object, updates the receiver if necessary, and reports (through the method changed) whether the receiver was updated. If the target is on an unmounted AppleShare volume, path automatically mounts the volume. If the target is on an unmounted ejectable volume, path asks the user to insert the volume.

After it identifies a target, path compares some key information about the target with the information in the receiver. If the information differs, path updates the receiver to match the target.

The path method displays the standard dialog boxes when it needs input from the user, such as a name and password for mounting a remote volume. The user can cancel the resolution through these dialog boxes.

resolveIfIsAliasFile:

Resolve alias file target. 

- (NDAlias *)resolveIfIsAliasFile:(BOOL *)wasSuccessful;
Return Value

A new NDAlias or the reserver

Discussion

If the receiver points to an alias file and it can be resolved, returns a new NDAlias to the original; else returns itself. wasSuccessful will be set to NO if some kind of error occured, such as the receiver being an alias file but unresolvable. If this is not of interest, you may pass NULL.

setAllowUserInteraction:

Option controls how the alias is resolved 

- (void)setAllowUserInteraction:(BOOL)flag;
Parameters
flag

YES to stop any user interaction.

Discussion

Sets wether the OS may present a user interface when resolving the receiver. By default, as of version 1.3, user interaction is not allowed. In previous versions, the default was to allow user interaction.

setPath:

Updates an the reciever with a new target. 

- (BOOL)setPath:(NSString *)path;
Parameters
path

the path for the target of the reciever.

Return Value

Returns YES if setting the target succeeded, otherwise returns NO.

Discussion

The method setPath: rebuilds the entire recievers alias record .

setPath:fromPath:

Updates an the reciever with a new target.

See Also:

setURL:fromURL:

- (BOOL)setPath:(NSString *)path fromPath:(NSString *)fromPath;
Parameters
path

the path for the target of the reciever.

fromPath

The starting point for a relative path, to be used later in a relative search. The two file or directory paths, fromPath and path, must reside on the same volume.

Discussion

The method setURL:fromURL: rebuilds the entire recievers alias record .

The setURL:fromURL: function always creates a complete alias record. When you use setURL:fromURL: to update a minimal alias record, you convert the minimal record to a complete record.

setTryFileIDFirst:

Option controls how the alias is resolved 

- (void)setTryFileIDFirst:(BOOL)flag;
Parameters
flag

YES to resolve the alias by trying file ID first, NO to try path first.

Discussion

Search for the alias target using file IDs before searching using the path. By default search by path occurs first.

setURL:

Updates an the reciever with a new target. 

- (BOOL)setURL:(NSURL *)URL;
Parameters
URL

the file url for the target of the alias.

Return Value

Returns YES if setting the target succeeded, otherwise returns NO.

Discussion

The method setURL: rebuilds the entire recievers alias record .

setURL:fromURL:

Updates an the reciever with a new target. 

- (BOOL)setURL:(NSURL *)URL fromURL:(NSURL *)fromURL;
Parameters
URL

the file url for the target of the reciever.

fromURL

The starting point for a relative path, to be used later in a relative search. The two file or directory url's, fromURL and URL, must reside on the same volume.

Return Value

Returns YES if setting the target succeeded, otherwise returns NO.

Discussion

The method setURL:fromURL: rebuilds the entire recievers alias record .

The setURL:fromURL: function always creates a complete alias record. When you use setURL:fromURL: to update a minimal alias record, you convert the minimal record to a complete record.

Updates an the reciever with a new target.

See Also:

- (BOOL)setPath:(NSString *)path fromPath:(NSString *)fromPath;
Parameters

the path for the target of the reciever.

tryFileIDFirst

Option controls how the alias is resolved 

- (BOOL)tryFileIDFirst;
Return Value

YES to resolve the alias by trying file ID first, NO to try path first.

Discussion

Search for the alias target using file IDs before searching using the path. By default search by path occurs first.

URL

Returns the single most likely target for the receiver. 

- (NSURL *)URL;
Return Value

A file NSURL to the target of the receiver. nil is returned if no target could be found.

Discussion

The URL method performs a fast search for the target of the receiver. If the resolution is successful, URL returns a file NSURL for the target file system object, updates the receiver if necessary, and reports (through the method changed) whether the receiver was updated. If the target is on an unmounted AppleShare volume, URL automatically mounts the volume. If the target is on an unmounted ejectable volume, URL asks the user to insert the volume.

After it identifies a target, URL compares some key information about the target with the information in the receiver. If the information differs, URL updates the receiver to match the target.

The URL method displays the standard dialog boxes when it needs input from the user, such as a name and password for mounting a remote volume. The user can cancel the resolution through these dialog boxes.
